author: {'steamid': '76561198152586557', 'num_games_owned': 508, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3029, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3021, 'last_played': 1636587823}
review:
Ok...Guns of Icarus, este juego fue de fama pronta y poco duradera, mucha de la cual se le atribuye al esfuerzo de Muse por promoverlo en un principio por Youtube y twitch con diferentes "celebridades" y el cual para ser honesto dio bastante resultado, el juego no vendio mal pero no logro mantener el influx de jugadores constantes y empezo a ir en decremento con el tiempo, y en realidad nunca entendi por que, el juego en si es un pvp/pve en el cual se emplean grandes dirigibles de estilo Steampunk, estos vienen en varios modelos y tienen sus ventajas y desventajas , ya sea un Squid que aunque es bastante rapido carece de armas y defensa en general, o un Corsair que es una nave colosal con 6 emplazamientos de armas, mucha armadura, razonable velocidad (eso si el squid siendo para pvp y el corsair para pve), hay un tipo de nave para cada persona y esta puede armarla como quiera en lo que a los emplazamientos se refiere (sin contar los cosmeticos ya que ese es otro tema).

El juego se basa en un cooperativo bastante fuerte para lograr mantener la nave a flote, tu y otros 3 miembros se tienen que encargar de mantener la nave en el aire cuando todo se este quemando y desplomandose al suelo, para esto cada miembro tiene un rol especifico de entre 3 especialidades disponibles.

-Capitan: es el que tiene control total de la nave y hacia donde dirigir la misma y cuenta con habilidades especiales para usar en situaciones dificiles, como invulnerabilidad en los motores, un boost de velocidad enorme para cargar contra naves, un amuleto para hacer que la nave gire mucho mas rapido, etc..., tambien en el papel es el que da las ordenes para los demas miembros, ya sea que reparen, disparen, etc...

-Artillero: miembro especializado en manejo de armas y diversos tipos de municion y puede llevar 3 tipos diferentes, tiene habilidades para soltar minas, empujar a las otras naves lejos con aire del globo, recargar las armas mas rapido y para girarlas mas rapido de igual manera, etc.

-Ingeniero: miembro que se encarga de mantener la nave a flote mientras todos corren en panico, tiene diferentes herramientas especializadas para diferentes labores, como la maza para reparar lo que no esta roto, la llave inglesa para reconstruir lo que ya esta roto, extinguidor para apagar llamas, spray quimico para hacer partes de la nave inmune al fuego, armas especiales de bufeo o incluso una maquina que repara sola las partes de la nave de manera mas lenta, y de igual manera cuenta con habilidades especiales como reconstruir todo lo que este roto de una vez, o inclusive un dron (Choppy) que se puede desplegar para que ataque a los enemigos y de algo de tiempo para escapar.

Eso si nada mas a tener en cuenta que las habilidades son para el Alliance y no para el pvp por razones de balance. El juego cumple bastante con lo que ofrece, y para lo que cuesta y la cantidad de contenido que tiene es bastanste razonable.

El juego esta lejos de estar muerto, el que no tenga 30mil jugadores simultaneos no significa que este en el olvido, a mucha gente le gusta exagerar y mas aun con el crossplay con ps4 casi siempre hay salas abiertas. Bueno al final solo puedo decir que es un muy buen juego, pero tal vez no sea para esos lobos solitarios que no les gusta trabajar en equipo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997632863', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 4717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4717, 'last_played': 1510978670}
review:
Wonderful game, I even supported the original Guns of Icarus.

Alas no matter how wonderful it is. A game that keeps crashing and crashing aint worth a penny. Save your money till its fixed....
developer_response:
Hi there!

Sorry to hear you’re having this problem. Lets have you try a few solutions below:

To make sure the build has downloaded properly. Right-click on the game in your game library, select Properties, go to the Local Files tab, and click Verify Integrity of Game Cache.

If that doesn't work lets have you try resetting your startup options:
1) Right-click on the game in your Steam library, go to Properties
2) Select "Set Launch Options"
3) Enter the text "--resetToDefaults" (no quotes) and hit OK
4) Launch the game
5) After you’ve done that remove the "--resetToDefaults"

It could be a DirectX matter, simply right-click on the game in the library select properties and a window should pop up showing 'Set Launch Options' as one of the buttons. In that text input enter: -force-d3d9.

You can also try disabling your Steam overlay when you start up the game to do this, right-click on the game in your Steam library, select ‘Properties' and uncheck the ‘activate Steam overlay' option. Press OK and start up the game again, this should result in a more stable launch for you.

Should none of these options work for you can I have you grab us a log file? Instructions are below:

On a PC, look for your client log file inside your Steam folder:
C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\guns of icarus online\GunsOfIcarusOnline_Data\output_log.txt

On a Mac, open the Console app in your Utilities folder. Find Unity on the side panel (it’ll be under ~/Library/Logs if it’s not expanded), and the file we need is player.log.

On Linux, look for your client log in the following directory:
~/.config/unity3d/Muse Games/GunsOfIcarusOnline

You can email this log to feedback@musegames.com and we'll take a closer look to help address this problem with you, thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198072173664', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5854, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5021, 'last_played': 1532356310}
review:
Updated 5/17/18

Short Opinion: 

still a dead game

Long Opinion :

  The player population is semi existent because they cross platformed with Playstation. However, the amount of turnover with players is a huge issue.  If you play the PVE you will be playing with mostly lvl 1-10 players.  This is a huge problem because these players always lack the basic knowledge of shootting armor and hull with the correct guns amongst other things.  So if you wanna play Guns of Noobs online and train crews constantly than have at it.  

The way the overall Alliance faction map works is still just a mystery to most. Not that its even worth talking about since its basically a moot point. The only thing people care about is leader spots in factions because its give a sense of personal pride to grind more efficiently than the others.

Playstation players also dont have the ability to join four ship lobbies so theres that.

Why you would even make nighttime maps, maybe because its a lazy way to make new content.

Alliance did not live up to the hype, its more of a dlc really.

Still has population issues.
developer_response:
Hi there! Almost missed people responding to this, sorry about that!

To clarify:
What we originally wanted is to make a new game and integrate the old one into it. Unfortunately Steam didn't offer an option for this, so now the way it works is that the Guns of Icarus Online client is actually just the Guns of Icarus Alliance game with all the content of Guns of Icarus Online, and buying Alliance will now seem like an upgrade.

There is no MTX in this game, and that was always really important to us. Being a small indie studio we can and want to take the stance that players shouldn't have to spend money to play a game. 

Cosmetics are purchasable, but you can also win them at our bi-weekly Fight The Devs games, we have given away over 300k items for free.

Tripel Coriander: I always recommend the community calendar. There is a huge hype with events, and they are guaranteed to have full lobbies :)
Let me know if you wanna jump on the game with us! I'd make time.

Thanks for responding
- B'Elanna

author: {'steamid': '76561198061740176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 273, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1506322258}
review:
Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sN9iK5Or0cQ

Guns of Icarus is an older game now, having release in 2012. In it you play as either a pilot, engineer, or gunner, and run an airship in arena-based battles of up to four ships versus four ships in PvP or four ships versus endless-ish ships in PvE. With 74 hours into the game I think it’s safe to say I’ve played a lot of it over the years. Not as much as others, but more than most.

So gameplay wise you’ll be limited to one role mainly for the entirety of each match. As a pilot you’ll get to steer the ship, use abilities to do anything from speeding the ship up, leaving toxic gas in your wake, or a number of other things. You’ll likely also be in the captain role and get to give orders to either your AI crewmates or player partners who will hopefully listen to you. Occasionally you might go to repair something as well at leave no one at the helm as you can carry one tool for every role you are not and three for your selected role, which allows some capability for crossover and strategizing.

As a gunner you’ll be mainly working on the guns, obviously. You can load your guns with specific ammunition with various effects from incendiary, to heatsink, and even explosive. Of course you might have to do some repairing of your own gun or maybe even of the ship if things get so dire.

As an engineer you will be running around frantically trying to repair things as they blow up, get set on fire, or get shot up. You’ll be able to repair things faster, rebuild things faster, put out fires, buff guns, or even auto-repair things. Sometimes you’ll also be asked to do some gunning if there’s nothing to repair

All of these classes balance each other out really well since no one class can quite completely do the role of another. They also even have special abilities they can use. Engineers can sprint, gunners can reload faster, and captains can move the ship faster and more maneuverable all for a limited time. All in all the gameplay base here is really solid and makes for a really enjoyable experience already.

The graphics are charming and unique but certainly not revolutionary or even “good” for that matter even back in 2012 when the game was released. There’s not really any heavy level of production to this game. It received just enough to not be void or ridiculous, but most attention really went off to the gameplay. There aren’t many issues really. Some multi monitor issues depending on your exact setup but that’s not necessarily the game’s fault as far as I know. For example my friend didn’t have any issues with that, but I did. However we use very different monitors and he runs AMD whereas I run Nvidia and AMD is admittedly much better with multi-monitor frameworks.

You can fully customize your ships with color designs and ornaments and set up exactly what guns you want on it. Your only real limitations in that regard are the things available and the weapon slots you have on every ship. Ships all have different stats. Some are better than others in different situations and excel at doing very specific things sometimes. There’s entire metas on how to play certain types of ships. Although I learned the hard way that things that work in PvP aren’t necessarily going to work in PvE.

The AI in both PvE and PvP are pretty incompetent. They’re not very smart, are a nightmare if you are trying to solo run a ship (although my friend who runs solo constantly disagrees with me, but he only plays PvE), and they just are dumb and do things wrong and play about as bad as a brand new player would. Meaning you shouldn’t really get this unless you plan on playing with other people and I’ll mention more on that later. You can’t really put AI into PvP matches, nor can you have an AI pilot a ship when a player is present or in a PvP match. They can only do that in PvE for some reason.

The game itself gets an 7/10 from me here. It’s a very fun solid base. There’s some small issues with the game itself, but just small things. For what this game tried to be it certainly nailed it on the head. Although admittedly it’s not actually that much so it’s nothing that deserves anything higher than an 8 no matter how well it does it. But this isn’t the end of this review. The most important point has yet to be made and it’s pretty negative and basically why I bumped a point off the score I wanted to give it.

Now this is where things are going to split up between Online and Alliance because this game is marketed very strangely and impractically and I can only recommend buying one of these two.

To start, Online is the PvP only edition of the game. It is the original game and you can pick it up for a mere $5. That sounds like a great deal, right? Well just wait. 

Alliance is the PvE expansion to the game. However, when you buy it you’re getting and paying for both the expansion AND the base game. It’s $15, meaning the price of the expansion is twice that of the original game. That’s a bit odd don’t you think? Well not so much.

Guns of Icarus had a very strong launch. Youtubers advertising it everywhere. Good marketing, good emails, and just solid work all around. It sold many copies and even successfully kickstarted an “adventure mode” which turned into Alliance (which is not even close to what adventure mode was supposed to be) and didn’t really receive any flak over it at all.

The huge issue here is that Guns of Icarus after a while had a very hard problem at maintaining its playerbase. Less than one month after its release there were over a thousand people playing it every day. At its peak there were nearly five thousand every day. This is in a game where you only really need eight people in one match for an optimal experience so these numbers are pretty good. After a while that number descended into only a few hundred every day and the daily peak was around four hundred. Still enjoyable, but harder to find a match given differences in skill level and all. Recently it’s gotten even worse. After the launch of PvE I think the developers just gave up trying to maintain a healthy PvP playerbase because now only a max of fifty to sixty people even play every day. The peak is about forty or fifty and during the night it will plummet down to ten people playing at once. And keep in mind this is across both PvE AND PvP. Ten people playing. A bare minimum PvP match without relying on AI needs eight players. A full one needs thirty two. That’s more people than you’ll even normally find online at this point. Because of this PvP is virtually nonexistent. You can’t find a match and if you can it’s small, uninhabited, and filled with AI.

The PvE fixes this a bit though because then you and a group of four friends or four of the other ten people playing the game can get together and take on endless hoards of AI. Technically you can have up to four ships of four so sixteen people fighting AI in several game modes, but you’re lucky at this point if you even sign on to see that many people online.

When it comes to Guns of Icarus Alliance then I’m going to have to recommend it; especially if you can rope some friends (preferably 3 others) into playing it with you. But do note that you’ll be supporting a company that is simply not trying anymore and that is trying to milk what they know is the last leg of their game by charging three time more than the dead PvP mode by its lonesome, which they’re STILL SELLING even though you can’t find a match to begin with.

I love this game, but the team behind it sucks. Don’t buy it support them. Only buy Alliance if you want to fight cooperatively against AI. PvP is dead and it’s never coming back. Remember. Fifty player peaks. And it only gets worse from here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198274548541', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 15687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15687, 'last_played': 1607233251}
review:
Guns of Icarus takes it's place as one of my most-played games in my entire life, with over 1.5k hours dedicated to it. The only thing that comes remotely close is my current investment in Final Fantasy XIV. That being said, this game was a gem. It's a diamond buried beneath a mountain of issues that plague it to this day, and I hope to god that one day, Muse or another developer looks at this game, it's concepts, it's heart and soul, and they see what I still see in it, almost 7 years on.

First and foremost, the game has stopped receiving updates beyond bug fixes and small balance adjustments, plus the occasional "we're gonna test this out to see what happens." I first started playing approximately one year before the Alliance DLC was set to launch, so I got a very good taste of the PVP aspect of the game before the PVE was introduced to "revitalize" everything. And it worked, more or less. But it wasn't enough to pull this beloved gem out of the dull veins it had been buried in. Alliance became the crutch for reasoning as to why the PVP mode stopped receiving updates. How come we haven't gotten a new map? The DLC takes priority. Why are some of these balance issues still in the game? We're working on Alliance. I couldn't tell you for certain if those were true and honest statements, and I don't have a problem believing them if they were. But 3 years on, it became an eyeroll to hear "please divert your feedback to our forums," and still getting told that the DLC was taking priority.

It's not a secret now that the original campaign pitch for "Adventure Mode" became what we know as the Alliance DLC. And while some aspects of the original pitch were present in Alliance, a lot of what people were REALLY excited for didn't make the cut. New maps and new gamemodes with a focus on vs AI combat, as well as the new ships, tools and guns that completely changed the way you played, all of that was added. And it gave us a lot to do for the first year or so. But there was no progression. There was nothing to work for. And after doing those same missions every week, pouring your resource coins into the same points every week, realizing Chaladon was a stacked faction and your only chance of fighting them was to be in the Baronies, when there's supposed to be six factions altogether, it was horribly monotonous. And hardly anything came around even after the DLC released publicly. 

The biggest appealing factor to me about Guns of Icarus getting a fully-fleshed out Adventure Mode would've been the story it could tell. The world of GOI is interesting to me, and while the combat was clearly enough to keep me playing when I was younger, that wasn't enough after a few years. When Alliance was first getting teased and we were given the run-down on all the factions, I was ecstatic for the potential world-building and story-telling at play! But nothing happened when you won certain points. There was no "major events" in the world, or in the game, to tell the player "hey, your choices are going to impact the story here!" That never happened. And it was disappointing, because the world had so much potential to tell any kind of story they wanted. And instead, they chose to let the game rot out until the only active members were the people who picked it up during a Steam sale and played for a few hours before dropping it completely.

The game can still be incredibly fun when played in clusters of friends or amidst community events. But those have more or less died. One of the last major events that was hosted for Guns of Icarus, the Chaos Skirmish, had it's final run last April, on the 7th anniversary since it originally started. Since then, reunions skirmishes spring up every few months. But the game is otherwise dead with an active playerbase of less than 30 people. And it's sad to see, when I know how much fun I used to have with all those people. But casually playing Guns of Icarus wouldn't happen unless you were happy with just playing the PVE mode and praying the AI were competent enough to shoot your guns while you flew the ship. 

I think one of the final nails in this game's coffin was the development team. There's a plethora of issues here, and there's some things that I couldn't publicly talk about for sake of privacy. But to give a concise summary, player vision and developer vision were the Sahara desert and the north pole. Feedback was typically poorly received, and more often than not, some developers were outright rude to their own playerbase. Not saying that every player was a ray of sunshine, but sometimes, there would be an innocent question from a new player, and startling yell of frustration from a developer. My own theory is that there was some internal disagreements as to where the game was supposed to go after Alliance was released, and it culminated in nothing getting done at the end of the day. The quality of updates staggered significantly after that first year of Alliance's release, leading to some incredibly unpolished maps, guns, balance changes, etc. 

The game ran rather poorly on anything with worse than a GTX 1660. I know because I have one, and it can barely reach 60 FPS some matches. During the intense moments in a game, I stumble down to 30 FPS. I used to play the game on worse hardware, and I'll be honest, I don't know how I tolerated it for the longest time. The dreaded clouds, or tar clouds specifically, would make FPS plummet, even worse if your ship was caught in one. And if you weren't used to stumbling around at 15 FPS, odds are your ship just sat there and bled to death.

To say some positives, the game still has that potential. When people get together and we're all just f*cking around and finding out, it's fun. It's exciting to try something new that you haven't done before, and go "holy shit, that worked!" Or to completely cock up your build and say "we'll make it work, everything's fine!!!" when the whole ship is on fire. There's a high skill ceiling when it comes to the combat of the game and how it all works together. But it's rewarding and satisfying to pull off. It's also fun to shout f*ck it, and plow straight at the enemy and see what happens.

The artstyle for this game is still a charm. Steampunk is one of my favourite aesthetics in any type of media, and Guns of Icarus' early outfits and ship designs have that down to a tee. I think some of the Alliance designs aren't quite what I would imagine, but it doesn't matter to me at the end of the day, since I already have my favourite outfit and favourite ship. Graphics are a little dated at this point, especially considering it still runs poorly on less optimized devices. But I think with some dusting off, most everything in the game is still up to par with modern expectancy of a game's visual quality. It doesn't have to be HDR and beautiful 4k rendering, since you're rarely gonna be watching your friend's character models for longer than a few seconds during combat. But it'd be nice to see it get some TLC. 

I stand by what I said originally, the game is a gem. There isn't anything quite like it, and there hasn't been for a very long time. But with lack of developer care, poor communication from said developers, and a dwindling playerbase with lessening patience for updates, the game is settling in its grave. And I will mourn what it used to be until the day Muse remembers what it was that gave this game heart and soul. 

(Totally buy it if it's on sale btw, it's cheap as hell as it is, and you might get to play a few fun games every few months if you join the CSS server, we're like a family over here ;3)

author: {'steamid': '76561198124391706', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 6815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3394, 'last_played': 1586200012}
review:
Yahu, bu elemanlar size ne etti?
Guns of Icarus Online, muhteşem bir oyun. Hemen hemen hiç bir eksiği olmayan, yıllar geçtikçe gerek grafik, gerek arayüz ve gerek event ve içerik olarak çok gelişen bir oyun (bir ara Skyball denen süper oyun modunu kaldırdılar, o ayrı konu)
Alliance ise, bu PvP moduna bağlı, süper, über gelişmiş ve ayrıntılı bir PvE/PvP modu. Ve, oyun o kadar ayrıntılı ki sistemini nasıl anlatacağımı kestiremiyorum şu anda. Bir sürü mükemmel ince ayar, ayrıntı, mevzu var.

Bu "yan oyun"da, bir faction seçiyor, çeşitli görevler ve çeşitli taktikler kullanarak (ki, inanın bana neredeyse sınırsız bu "taktik"ler! Dengelemeler mükemmel!) "war effort" elde ediyor ve bir miktar ganimet topluyorsunuz. Bu war effortlar, haritada belirlediğiniz (faction olarak belirlemek, herkesle birlikte hareket etmek en doğrusu) noktalarda saldırı ya da savunma yapabiliyor, o bölgelere asker yığabiliyor, var olan kaleleri güçlendirebiliyor, düşman görevlerine sabotaj düzenleyebiliyor... Çeşitli kaynaklarda üst sınırı toplayan faction olunca da, factionlar bölünmeye ve allianceler oluşturmaya başlıyorlar, çünkü oyun gelişmiş oluyor. Bu defa, oyuna da adını veren alliancelerin çok daha çetin ve hırslı savaşına tanıklık ediyoruz. Ve, tüm bunlar, oyunun "lore" kitabına hikaye olarak işliyor. Süper emek mi harcadınız? Delice taktiklerinizle düşmanı alt etmeyi mi başardınız? Adınız unutulmayacak ve efsaneniz hikayelerle nesiller boyu aktarılacak!
Yahu, milyar ayrı güzellik var bu oyunda. Alın, aldırın.

Belirtmem gereken bir konu var. Şu anda oyuncu sayısı az. Çünkü, öğrenmesi birazcık emek isteyen bir oyun. Ama sıradan bir oyun ne kadarını sizden talep ediyorsa, bu da o kadarını ediyor. Sadece... Sosyal olmanız lazım. Sormanız, soruşturmanız, anlamaya çalışmanız ve yağtığınız şeyleri (özellikle tayfnaın kaptanıysanız) açıklamanız lazım. Oyuna girip beyni dönen birkaç oyuncu devamını getirmiyor haliyle. Ama, o kadar yıl oldu, hala oyuncu bulmakta zorlanmıyorum. Çat diye girebiliyorum. Çünkü, daima birileri var oralarda.

Eğer harhangi bir şeyi sormak veyahut birileriyle oynamak isterseniz, oyun içinde de aynı niki kullanıyorum. Her türlü sorunuza itinayla cevap verir, hemen her konuda destek olurum.
Zamanında bir de facebook/steam/discord grubu (Guns of Icarus Online TR) kurmuştum Türkçe konuşan oyuncular bir araya gelebilsin diye ama benim dışımda kimse yok şimdilik. Haberiniz olsun. Arada paylaşım yapıyorum :)

NOT: Ana oyundan ziyade Alliance paketini satın alın derim. Hem içerik sayısı inanılmaz daha fazla, hem de ana oyun da sizinle birlikte geliyor.
NOT 2: Ana oyundaki saatim çok daha fazla. Çünkü arada birkaç yıllık süre var :) Ama Alliance ile geçirilen zaman artık ana oyuna da süre olarak işliyor. Endişelenmeyin o konuda.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002540828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 777, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 775, 'last_played': 1506933378}
review:
My friends and I are having a great time playing this! Lots of laughs, shouting and excitement. The three different roles of pilot, gunner, and engineer offers something for everyone. 

Definitely recommend you play the tutorials and do some practice before attempting an actual mission. Only negative, one of us had some crashes during play, but switching to the DX9 version seems to have fixed that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054921950', 'num_games_owned': 566, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1505222964}
review:
this is a game that requires you to co-operate with other people in order to effectively run your airship. co-op isnt the problem here, the co-op is fine and the game is really enjoyable. the guns feel good to shoot, the ships feel good to fly. enviroments provide fun challenges. but the problem is that nobody is playing it. a look on the steam charts shows that its all time peak was 377. in the last 24 hours of writing this the peak was 58 players. the game is fun, works well. but theres nobody playing it. and its a game that you need to play multiplayer. especially with the pve. i'd reccomend this game if it has a player base, i'd still say its good. but i cant reccomend it because of how dead the online seems to be. if you and some friends want to try this game out then go for it, but if you're not getting it with friends you probably wont be able to find a game to play in. so if you're  thinking of playing with strangers i cant reccomend spending your money on it. i played online a bunch and the data from online transfers over. but because i wasnt able to find anyone online i couldnt even tell you about the new things that were added.

tl:dr dont buy this game if you're playing by yourself. the community just isnt there to make it playable

author: {'steamid': '76561198078654912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1594842601}
review:
edit: my initial review was like ultra harsh cuz i was angry so i dulled it down to a rational complaint 

If you have no interest in co-op against bots, just buy the original Guns of Icarus. I bought this game because I thought my friends might want to try the game out again after not playing for many years, and the first sign i could tell something was amiss was when the download was only 140 mb. When I saw that it said i was running both of the games at the same time, and the exact same sequence from when i launched the first game showed up I got legitimately freaked out because i thought my game was messed up somehow. But no, my game was fine, its just that Alliance is like the equivalent of a DLC expansion that adds a few different aspects but somehow costs more than the multiplayer aspect. I don't know if researching the game itself more might've helped me not end up at this destination, but the fact of the matter is, I thought Alliance was a DIFFERENT, NEWER version of the Guns of Icarus that I really enjoyed so much, and am annoyed with the actual outcome of my discovery.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089700987', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 15361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8451, 'last_played': 1705701897}
review:
This dlc basically added faction roleplay mode. 
While I dont like it when you are taking rp too serious, this update feels like they hired a Chef to determine the exact amount of rp spicing, they can put in. You have an individual choice of faction (which can be changed later) with which you will fight for territories on the dynamic map. The faction leaders are chosen in short intervalls, whcih means its easy to be a leader if you do a lot  for your faction. Since the leaders are elected by their contribution to the faction, you can expect the leaders to be A. The Achievement hunters B. Really good players or C. People that take the faction ( and rp) serious enough that they want to be a faction leader  all the time. As a faction leader it is advised to discuss battle strategies with your fellow leaders, but conversations between leaders can be about literally anything. Don´t belive me? Alright then, let me give you an example of the most funny thing I have seen long time faction leaders do a (semi) serious conversation about:

AN ARMY.....

OF TALKING TOASTERS WITH WEAPON KNOWLEDGE, manufactured by a small group of mercenaries from all the different factions, so the plans dont get into enemy hands ( I know there is sometimes a shortage of gunners but wtf)


Sometimes I fell like this is Politics in a nutshell. 
So there you have it: you basically have a pve mode with more ships, more guns, abilities and Politics.
would I recommend you buying this?
MOST DEFINITELY!!!!  It can be boring every now and then when there  are not much players online, but spend one evening with a group of 15 total strangers that ( in the game context) are your comrades , that treat you like you are their friend and you will know why I love this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198059180552', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1515527367}

author: {'steamid': '76561198104470300', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 50573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3038, 'last_played': 1710541889}
review: intense, fun, love the community lore added after each war

author: {'steamid': '76561198054088218', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1608734956}
review:
Really like this game, for me its been a one of a kinda experience.

Pros
Unique 
Customize-able ships (for gun choices)
Good with friends as it involves teamwork
Lots of replayability with pve, pvp and lvl progression
Many difficulty choices for pve catering for new players to veterans alike
Nice community
Nice faction features with unique things that can be unlocked for other factions after you've reached a certain lvl
Role lvls, different roles have different lvls and you have an overall lvl that is an average of all of them gives a more accurate gage of skill

Cons
Not too many players
PVP can be a stomp since theres not too many players
Shipload outs are completely dependant on the captain

Overall if you have friends to play with in the same region its definitly worth your money or if you enjoy these kind of games really.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973112890', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1505343739}
review:
The last time I had this much trouble with a game demanding all sorts of ID before I could even play the campaign was Blizzard shit and I never bought from them again, but at least when I sent an IRL ID I could play it,

Downs, so much down
This game is completely unplayable for me. retry in 5 sec after every single attempted action, the verification code to my account never even showed up in the spam folder, try another time out and retry connection etc,

To be honest I don't even really know what this game is like. It feels more like a gimmick or dealing with an annoying phone tree than a real thing meant to help and entertain you, speaking of which, what freaking help?

I really wanted not to but on those grounds alone downrated until the devs fix their s&%#

And had I known this was online exclusive I never would have bought it during the sale

author: {'steamid': '76561198014790787', 'num_games_owned': 1046, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1542, 'last_played': 1692054994}
review:
This has been out a while so my review wont do much harm but I get to finally vent.

The overall very positive reviews is very misleading.  Most of them is from the hardcore player base that has stuck around since the beginning.  Or community ambassadors.  Not to mention there are very few reviews to begin with.  

All Alliance did was kill PVP in general.  Split the player base till there was nothing left in PVP.  Why you all decided to go for the colorful fancy pants designs of the ships in Alliance mode versus the post apocalyptic vibe that was compelling I will never understand.  And then insult to injury adding those ridiculous ships to PVP.  That was nail in the coffin for me.

Review of gameplay:  Chaos.  No ryhme or reason much anymore.  Playing AI who have very few tactical approaches.  Ram you or shoot you.  Best part of Goio was the mind games.  Little airplanes dive bombing you?  Why?  Those ships dont fit in anywhere in lore or otherwise.   Its all senseless nonsense.

But the real kicker is the years of not listening to the community.  The balance changes that nerfed and buffed shit that didnt need to be buffed or nerfed,  the blatant disregard for its player base and their opinions.  listening to people that self-appointed themselves as our community ambassadors (ATRUEJEDI)  and Muse listening to them instead of us,  it all just took a huge toll.  On not just me. MANY.

I could go on,  but I wasted enough time as it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140345639', 'num_games_owned': 142, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5134, 'last_played': 1654538209}
review:
Points forts du jeu :

-Une très belle ambiance. Des graphismes très convenables, une belle Ost, des design de vaisseaux et personnages originaux et attachants.

-Une variété correcte : possibilité de jouer en PvE comme en PvP, et possède dans chacune des deux options plusieurs modes (protection d'une base, parcours d'infiltration ou survie par vague, ect... en PvE, match classique, système de capture de points, ect...en PvP)

-De nombreux vaisseaux équilibrés et diversifiés, le système de deck pour l'armement des dirigeable comme des outils des personnage est bien pensé.

-Un système de faction sympatique et assez prenant, basé sur une carte évoluant en fonction des joueurs. Avec en plus une progression personnelle au sein de la faction permettant de débloquer un vaisseau et une arme spécifique à cette dernière (ceux des autres faction se débloquent après coup via un achievement)

-Très fun. En PvE comme en PvP, à plusieurs. La communauté est dans son ensemble sympatique et le jeu peu à la fois se jouer de manière très stratégique comme de manière plus relâchée, tout dépendra des niveaux de difficulté choisis.

-Très soutenu par les développeurs : event nombreux et réguliers.



Points faibles du jeu :

-Si l'on peut jouer en solo, c'est très fortement déconseillé, le jeu peut devenir frustrant et monotone, les IA n'étant pas les compagnons de vol idéaux, est vraiment fait pour jouer à plusieurs.

-Peut parfois paraître redondant, surtout en PvE, lors des séances de farm pour le classement de la faction.

-Peut parfois planter de temps à autre, quelques bug par endroits, rien de très graves, cependant.

-Peut paraître un peu cher. N'étant à la base qu'un DLC de la version PvP qui ne coûte que 5 euros.

-La progression peut paraître un peu longue, si l'on est pas un hardcore gamer.

-De temps à autre, les joueurs se font rare, trouver un match peut-être compliqué.



En résumé, selon moi, un très bon jeu, pas parfait, mais très bon, a essayer, entre amis, pour des heures de fun !

author: {'steamid': '76561198071052682', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1499743919}
review: This game is awesome, but I have only gotten to play it like twice because there's never enough players online to fill a full lobby. I literally threw my money away and got an unplayable game because it's only me and like 7 other people playing it apparently. The game itself is amazing and I really wish more people bought and played it but I have to say that right now it's not worth the money because you wont get to actually play it ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990509668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1683071745}
review:
It is truly a shame, but I don't recommend this game to no one. Despite the fact that Muse Games had a very cleaver idea when they thought of creating a steampunk-ish scenario, (there aren't many steam punks pvp/co-op flight simulators around) I feel like the lack of company experience and poor implementation prevailed. There are quite a few downsides to the game that are sure to make your gameplay the worst possible. I won't even cover the discussion about Guns of Icarus Alliance being charged as a separate game when it was actually promised as what Guns of Icarus Online should be after being developed.

- Despite the advertising of having a growing community, Guns of Icarus Alliance doesn't. This makes the matchmaking proccess a lot longer than it should. You can easily wait for 20 minutes to get your room set-up with all players and have your game last just as much as you waited for. Muse even presented a way out for this, creating single player missions, but they just feel like a band-aid to a much bigger problem.

- Character costumization isn't that great. Since there are few achievments for each class, you basically get different clothes based on your level, meaning that every level 20 will have the same possibilities, except for the color you use to dye your outfits (or if you pay good coin to get exclusive content). 

- Poor controller compatibility. I've played the game for almost two years now and virtually no updates were focused on improving the experience for players that use controllers. Not only you cannot have access to each action on your controller, but there are also a lot of buttons that don't do anything, which just makes it look like they just focused elsewhere.

Lastly (and also the main reason I'm writing this) we have the costumer service. There simply isn't one. I've addressed Muse Games with a question about driver compatibility and I was answered with an automatic message asking about my firewall ports. After replying that my problem wasn't internet related, I never got an answer back. I've been waiting for two months now (being unable to play the game) and nothing. Such disrespect is unacceptable with the gaming community.

review: This game has an amazing community. I usually stay away from online multiplayer games, but this game is an exception to that usual rule for me. The gameplay itself it's good too. There are balance systems imbedded in the game play to try and keep things fair and fun. That being said, it can get a bit repetitive after a while so be sure to do it with some friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982403843', 'num_games_owned': 1244, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1497557892}
review:
TLDR - Save your money and look elsewhere. You won't have an opportunity to play this good game with such a low player base unfortunately. Also, don't support devs that split player bases with DLC and faulty advertising.

Bought this thinking it was a sequel or the next in the series of Guns of Icarus. However, turns out it was a DLC for the base game Guns of Icarus Online. The community was already very small for this multiplayer game so splitting it further with this DLC was a horrible move by the developers.

Yes, you could knock me down a couple points for not doing more research to determine this was DLC and not a new game to take the series further as a sequel normally would. However, the point here is that splitting the already small number of players even further was a huge mistake. No level of effort on matchmaking have I even been able to get a game where more than 2-3 players joined for a match in which you need 10.

I love the concept of crew gameplay where you have different station and need to fight other airships with their own crew. I've gotten some good experiences out of the original game, but sadly it's come to an end because the player base isn't there.

There are some single player modes in game where you can play with bots, but the experience is just not the same because the enemy AI is just not a challenge. When raising the difficulty to higher levels the enemy ships just become bullet sponges and do not try more sophistacted tactics or prove a challenge in that realm. They simply do more damage and take more damage. Artificial difficulty with bots does not replace a competitive environment with enemy human players.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993293102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1568672396}
review: 4 teammates, frantically putting out fires, setting fire to other ships, and ramming the hell out of each other -- in flight!  This is a well executed game that is simple to pick up, but has enough depth to the combat that it makes it fun.  Much better than I was expecting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032707250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1668792063}
review:
I played GoI for about 155 hrs and when GoI Alliance came out iI was kinda skeptical about it. The way this dlc was promoted didn't sitt well with me. In he End I bought the game due to a low player base in GoI and what can I say the new game does not only not give old players a little thank you it seems like a plan B solution.

What do I mean with that?
- There are new maps, but most of them are restricted to certain modes
- the hitboxes are a little bit off.
- The PVE is as boring as can be, with unispired WKII airplaines, freely in your back spawning Blibs and a big varity of missions. Like the one where you have to destroy a few stations, while under enemy fire, or the one where you have to standby in a reach of enemy bases til they self destruct while under enemy fire... you get the point.
- The grafics actually look worse than in the original when it comes to verything that is not on a ship
- But theree are factions now. There is quite a bit of lore for them if you are interested, but if not, every faction has a new ship and a new weapon. Also they have a never ending war on who wears the most stupid uniform ( I think they are all winners).
- Than there is this faction war thing. Honestly I dind't look much into this, but it seems like you can deploy in a war zone , which doesn't mean you actually get to fight there. No, you just do normal missions an get gold for that and a bit of poionts for the deployment zone. The gold you can use in the deployment zones too. If you factions has enough points you win the territory and get a ressource. This thing is, wht's really makes me believe that this wasn't the original plan.
- You can play pve with just one ship now (probably interesting for old goi players, but it seems to be a cure and an ilness for the game, due to it's low player count).
- also the workshop still isn't a real workshop, its more like steam greenlight for stuff.

Can I recoment this game? Yes but not in good conscious.But I will probably give it another chance or two and update this post if I find something interesting .

author: {'steamid': '76561197968107996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 12111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2, 'playtime_at_review': 2352, 'last_played': 1712144610}
review:
Other reviewers complain about a lack of games to join and a horrible playerbase, but honestly I can't say I've had the same experience.  There are always games to join, even during off-hours, and after some 50+ or so games I've only had two people complain in a match (to be fair, they were mostly co-op matches, maybe the pvp matches are worse).

The game's strength is in how well it balances first-person action with strategy elements, though I could see that being a con for some, as you really have to be good at both in this game.  The learning curve might be a bit high for people who just want to shoot things, and the action might be a little too fast-paced for those who only care about tactical battles.  For those who like both, however, the game is amazing, and best of all it's wrapped up in a wonderfully detailed steampunk setting.   

Overall, I've had a great time in the game, and after 30 hours or so I still feel like I'm only scratching the surface of strategies and techniques.  Between the different roles/ships/loadouts there are a lot of possibilities for customizing your playstyle.  There are some problems with the game (obtuse UI, and a lack of an easy way to coordinate with your faction), but the core gameplay is solid and definitely worth the asking price if you are new to the game. Edit: After 100 hours, I still recommend this game. I don't play daily like I used to, but I do come back every once in a while for a few games here and there. Pretty good deal considering the price of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042161491', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1498181307}
review:
Sad to rate this thumbs down, but... Alliance doesn't really offer anything of particular value over the base game, despite being four times the price. It's a Facebook game strapped on top of boring, repetiving PvE "scenarios" where you can grind experience and goal to unlock lackluster a handful of ships and weapons you can use to grind experience and gold.

For 20 dollars, I'd have expected an actual *campaign* mode of some sort - like the promotional materials offered, traveling from place to place, building and upgrading your ship, doing missions. This doesn't really have any of that. It's got a "factions map" where you juggle numbers around for no particular reason towards no particular end.

Worse, it seems to have doubled down on the cosmetic item prices. When it was a cheap PvE game that was fine, but it means the sort of stuff you might want to play the PvE mode for will remain locked behind that paywall.

Overall a frustrating and disappointing experience. It took a great PvE game and added a way for you to grind against bots for absolutely no purpose.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995318720', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1317, 'last_played': 1500765282}
review:
Ever wanted to be an airship captain? Shout at your crewmates and burn down your enemys? Well in Guns of Icarus you can do just that which is a ton of fun to be honest!

I played this game for quite a few hours now together with my flatmate me being the captain and him being the gunner which is tons of fun! Though i have to say it is more fun together in the same room mostly to being able to look at his screen to help me steer or for the better communication. Everytime I play by myself with a random crew i gotta say its alot harder due to not being able to see alot from the ships helm on most hulls. So hardly advised to play it with friends for the best communication which actually enables to even tackle the higher difficulties in PvE mode!

The game in itself is solid and as far as i could see mostly bugfree can't say much about the PvP-part of the game since I didn't try it out myself so far.

The game got great potential and with some tweaking and comming patches i can only expect it to gain more depth and fun!

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198022992061', 'num_games_owned': 637, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 2086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2086, 'last_played': 1494318512}
review:
1つの船（飛行船）を4人で動かしつつ戦うゲーム。最大4隻。
4人と言っても友達5人以上で2人と3人とかに分かれて2～4隻で同じチームでも出撃可能。
人が足りないところはNPCが担当する事になる。
ゲーム形式はWorld of TankやWar thunderのようなマッチ形式。

基本的にどの飛行船も砲門数と修理箇所を考えると人数が足りない設定なので操舵を担当する船長（Captain）以外は船の中を走り回って攻撃＆修理する事になる。

PvPだけのGoIOnlineは初めから全ての船をいじれるが逆にそれだけなので飽きるのが早かった。
PvEでは戦闘に参加したりしてスキルや船、新しい砲をアンロックする事ができて楽しみが増えた。

船はアーマー（Armor)と船体（Hull)の耐久度があって、砲はそれぞれ対アーマーや船体向け等の砲があるので船長役はそれらの砲をどういう風に配置するか考えたりするのは面白い。

ただ、船長は実際のところ砲座につくことは稀なので自分が配置した砲が効率的なのか、射角が取れているのかが実は分からない。（ラムアタックできるので船長も操船しながら攻撃できます）
そもそも気に入って使っている船が実は乗組員からしたらものすごく修理個所がめんどくさい配置だったりする。

なのでソロプレイは不向きで知り合いなどで「3時下方向に敵船！」とか「射角がとれないよ！もうちょい左！」とか言いつつワイワイやりながら戦闘が終わった後に「あの船の修理箇所どうだった？」とか「砲の配置、あれでアーマーと船体削れた？」するとかなり楽しい。

ただ、なんだろう。
個人的に底が浅いというか比較して悪いけれど、上記のWoTやWT、World of Warships等に比べて中毒性が低く思える。
それが船の種類のせいなのか、ゲーム性なのかは自分でもわからないので合う人、合わない人はどのゲームでもいえるけれどあると思います。

上記のように友人たちと一つの船をみんなで動かす一体感とかはすごく楽しいのでオススメではあるのですけれど・・・。

アップデートで船が増えたりスキルが増えたりしているので今後に期待。
あと、実績を気にする人は気を付けて下さい、数が半端ないです、GoIOと共通なので解除されるときは両方解除されて画面上部にずらずらずらーっと実績解除されるのは気持ちいいですがなんせ数が・・・・。

author: {'steamid': '76561197989790791', 'num_games_owned': 400, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1496412448}
review:
Never in my life have I seen a worse UI than the one in Alliance. It's busy, it's confusing, and has absolutely no flow or hierarchy of information. There are far too many menus to find what you want, and the buttons are all over the place. The terrible part of this UI is that it must be MUSE's 4th or 5th attempt at designing the UI. I have never seen a company try and fail so many times at something most college level graphic designers can master.

Alliance still uses the matchmaker for it's multiplayer matches. This thing has been a terrible inconvenience (at best) since it's introduction a few years ago in the original Icarus game. It is in fact so useless that many devs and interns at MUSE recommend using an in-game work around to it. The community has never been large enough for it to work, and it's been a detriment to the game for years.

The ships in Alliance are a disaster, which is in stark contrast to the beautiful ships from the original Icarus game. In the original Icarus game every ship looked plausible. Every ship looked like it was designed from either a need for functionality, or put together to be as functionable as it could be (the junker). In the original Icarus, gun positions and arcs seemed to have a thought out purpose for their locations. If you look over every ship with your eyes, you'll see that every piece of those ships is there for a reason.

Run your eyes over the ships in Alliance. Not one of them makes sense. They are jarringly erratic in design, and most seem to lack any reason for their designs. Take for example the Judgement ship. It has smokestacks on top of it's balloon. Why are they there? What are they connected to? What purpose do they serve? Or look at the Magnate; it has walkways with rail guards for some of the way, but then those railings just stop, and that walkway continues, with nothing stopping you from a fall. Who realistically would design a ship like that? Would you walk around on something like that? These are just some of the many design "WTF's?!" that every ship in this g ame has. Just design for design's sake, with zero thought for functionality. Whoever designed these Alliance ships needs to have a long talk with the designer of the original Icarus ships.

The issue with the Alliance ships isn't just functionality or design, it's actual mechanics as well. Going back to the original Icarus ships, each has a distinct play style, tactical uses, and configuration of gun placements that make sense to each ship's overall design. In Alliance, not so much. I couldn't describe to you the unique role for each ship in Alliance because every ship functions, handles, turns, and flies very similiar to each other. There is no variety in styles or tactics. The gun placements on every Alliance ship is the worst part of the whole design! The placement and arcs of these guns seems erratic, as if someone just chose at random the placement for each gun on each ship. There is no advantage I can see for using any of the Alliance ships over thir much older, and much better designed original Icarus ships.

In short, the key feature of this airship game- the airships, are a mess. A terribly designed, insipid, candy-coated disaster. If there is any reason to not play this game, it's because they key feature of it fails to deliver across the board.

I have 44 friends on my steam list that own Alliance, and 77 friends who own the original Icarus game. Of that number, only 2 of my friends recommend this game throuh Steam (one of them is a MUSE employee). I cannot in any capacity recommend Alliance to anyone. This game fails to deliver in even the most basic aspects, such as UI, and is simply not worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028485092', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1255, 'last_played': 1592753940}

author: {'steamid': '76561198138326576', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1496361637}
review:
Wow... Uhhhhh where do I start?

[h1]A primer:[/h1]

I had the orginal Guns of Icarus Online back when it was popular (Logged about 42 Hours on it). The game itself is alot of fun dont get me wrong. However, without the playerbase numbers it used to have you simply just dont have a community to fuel a game type like this. Dont get me wrong: I love GOI, but I have some heartburn with this "game".

(For Referance:

Online = Guns of Icarus Online
Alliance = Guns of Icarus Alliance)

[h1]What is Alliance?:[/h1]

Alliance fixes a MAJOR issue Online had, the lack of PVE. Something that honestly could have kept the game alive from the start imo. However, today its released as a 20 Dollar DLC to a 5 Dollar game, which considering how little content is actually added? It seems more like a money grab than anything. While it acts like an actual game on the steam store it actually needs Online to function. To rectify this issue they actually bundle Online with Alliance and basically just leave Online (which was once the actual game provided by these people) as a now gimp'd version of Alliance. Stupid? Yes. It kinda spits on people who bough Online for full price back in its prime because now its basically just 5 bucks off this new game.

[h1]FAQ:[/h1]

[list]
[*]Do I need to buy Guns of Icarus Online for this game to work?

   No, the game is bundled with Alliance, it seems that Muse's scope for this game changed rapidly multiple times and is listed as both a base game and DLC on their own FAQ part of their site. So naturally there is confusion there when it seems even the publisher doesnt know what this game is

[*]How good is the player base?

   Pretty empty, buy this game with friends. Otherwise its so low you'll be waiting forever to find a game. Plus Pubbies sometimes arent the best of players. Play with people you can communicate with and know are in your skill set

[*]You said that its not really added much content? What got added?

   Basically? Factions. New ships and guns [u]THAT YOU HAVE TO LEVEL UP TO UNLOCK[/u] and just PVE mode where what you do is go around and fight your way through multiple enemy ships and not die as you shoot the oil rigs/manufacture plants/etc over and over and over again. Its the same search and destroy stuff repeatedly. Its pretty lackluster.

[*]You have to level up for the new ships and guns?

   Yes, you do. and from an hour of play? I didnt even level up once. You need to grind pretty hard to make any decent progress it seems and quite frankly? The gameplay is repetititve too. Rush B and destroy the tower and move on with your day at full speed.

[h1]The Review:[/h1]

This game is pretty solid gameplay wise, dont get me wrong. It does what its meant to. you get on a flying boat with a giant freakin ballon taped to the top of it by some jank manner, add a few guns, and you play the worlds most hardcore game of battleship but instead its in the sky, steampunk, and you can move in all 3 Axis at will. Different ships offer different weapon mountpoints and each have their own stats. Pretty solid and fun if you're new. Grab a bunch of friends and get to gether and just go ham working together and its even better.

That said if you're one of those early adopters from Online? This.... really doesnt seem that great. For 20 bucks or whatever price you get it on sale you literally buy the same game you bough back in 2012-whenever Alliance came out but with PVE and a pitiful discount. Good job Muse, this really does screw over your early adopter playerbase. If i got a notification that said: Hey alliance is like 5 bucks for you since you had Guns of Icarus Online before Alliance's release. I would say Hey man its 5 bucks, grab my buddies who used to play Online and we all hop back on. That's how you breath some life back into a playerbase by bringing the vets back who will likely be dedicated to the game if the content is good.

However..... Muse decided to screw up and offer for a limited time no less the "Discount" they gave to those who already had Online. You still get gimp'd 15 dollars for a world map, factions, and shiny toys you have to grind to unlock. 

[b]NOT COOL[/b]

20-15 bucks is what this game is worth without a sale if you're completely new to this francise. NOT something you should have to pay for literally buying the base game a couple years back. Not to mention that you dont even get an extra copy of Online if you already have it Which would have made this a bit more worth it if you did. Which really does completely screw the customer here.

Furthermore: The gameplay thats added is..... lackluster....

Drive, Shoot stationary target while rushing through a crowd of AI ships to not die, kill said target, rush to it, repeat.

There really isnt any challenge here. And if you know what you're doing its even less difficult. Theres no massive 4 crew battles, theres not enough playerbase to support it, and if you're lucky you'll find a 2 crew battle MAYBE a 3 crew. 

On top of this you are only paying for:
-A rather repetitive game mode
-New stuff you have to grind to unlock anyway
-A world map that probably wont get much action due to poor player base counts or will be dominated by a clan that snowballs
-Some new maps to play on

Thats.... really it. Not much else. And the grinding is SLOW. When you're level 1 in a faction you'd expect a few wins and a loss to result in at least SOME EXP that gets you out of level one in said faction.

Nope, barely over halfway..... greeeeeeeeaaaaat. And you need to hit presumably something more akin to a prestiege to unlock the other factions ships so you can use them. Let alone the painful grind to levels 6-8 to just unlock your factions special weapon and ship.

This has just resulted in some really poor incentive to play. The player feels like they're getting nowhere and the content they PAYED MONEY FOR is something they cant even use because of a steep level gap. Which I personally cant justify under any reason. This is hindered further if you're solo. Because you'll struggle to find the games to even gain EXP with to begin with if you dont wanna just constantly rely off AI gunman/engineers constantly. Which is stupid anyway.

At least with a few friends you can play multiple roles and switch in and out and have a blast together, not constantly get railed by a poor playerbase.

[h1]Pros & Cons[/h1]

[i]Pros and Cons are weighted by "+" or "-" symbols respectivly, 1 being not too impactful, 3 being very impactful to the game and its quality[/i]

[u]Pros:[/u]
+Fun with friends (you'd need 3 plus yourself at a minimum)
+Good Visuals
+Solid gameplay 
+Rather extensive character customization which is nice
+The items you can take for loadouts are pretty well balanced
+It seems Muse will continue to support this game

[u]Cons:[/u]
---Almost impossible to unlock any of the weapons/ships solo rendering a solid portion of this DLC unsuable which for 20 bucks they should all be automatically unlocked for you
---Repetitive PVE
---Massive price for what is really just a standalone DLC that should be 5 bucks, 10 for the Online/Aliance bundle
---If you own Online you're screwed. You get secondhand updates from the Alliance update pipeline. Its an afterthought by this point. Not a good way to treat past customers Muse. 
--Nearly dead player base
--Some people have complained of crashes and visual issues
--The playerbase CAN be toxic. Especially if you deny a reccomended loadout or run something that somebody doesnt like.
--8 Dollar costume pack? Really Muse? You're bleeding your playerbase as it is.
-Some weapons tend to have a must have ammo type. Like Greased in the gatling gun.

[h1]Overall Rating:[/h1]

[b]2/10[/b]

[i]You screwed yourself Muse. You overcharged for this DLC that should be a 10 dollar bundle for Online and Alliance, 5 for those who already have Online. Your steep price isnt going to put any extra life into this dying game's playerbase. I am refunding this "game"[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198011677292', 'num_games_owned': 373, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1697095555}
review:
Alliance is an improved and expanded version of Guns of Icarus containing both the base game and the expansion the release is named after. 

I've been playing Alliance since long before the Alpha went temporarily public (so I've been at it for about a year now). I'm quite happy with how well the release turned out as far as content is concerned. So, while it's not the open-world RPG-like experience many of us were expecting when the kickstarter took place, Alliance's co-op sets a good pathway for a greater future in the life of Guns of Icarus. It's a step in the right direction, and I'm excited to think of what might be achieved in the future, hoping towards the fulfillment of the dreams had when "Adventure Mode" was first conceived.

All in all, solid gameplay. It may get repetitive here and there but I like it that way. Interactions between factions get pretty cheesy at times, specially when some of us start getting into our characters and go full lore junkie on others. It's great casual fun and it feels great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025198900', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 6179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1710024856}
review:
Forenote: I've been playing Alliance since launch, just not via the actual Alliance launcher, so the hours are misleading.

While not quite as "open world" as originally discussed on Kickstarter, Alliance mode forges forward with a whole new vibe of teamwork and gameplay. I know a lot of people are very concerned that it hasn't "lived up to its hype", but what we have now is a stable, fun system that the devs can now expand on as we go.

Alliance brings some -much- needed PvE to the game, which finally ends the unfortunately imbalanced PvP matches for new players. I know a huge amount of people who refused to play, or stopped playing, because of many of the PvP matches being reputably hit-and-miss. A new player who loses 0-5 in their first ten matches because of stacked teams is basically just going to walk out the door and not look back. I almost did the same when I was new.

PvE allows new players to learn the ropes in games with reliable difficulty options. They can explore the ships, try all the weapons, experience the player tools, and practice their tactics with friends before trying out PvP.

I think with a dedicated PvE mode (and considering how often GOI has been included in sale bundles), we'll see a steady increase in players, and less people will be put off by the PvP since they'll have something else to try out instead.

Spread the word! Get your friends interested. Show them the game, get them to buy it. The more support the devs can get, the more they can improve Alliance mode to be like the dream we had for it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197974447355', 'num_games_owned': 515, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1494211231}

author: {'steamid': '76561198032114058', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 5641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3206, 'last_played': 1511124144}
review:
Edit: I will update this as Alliance improves. The Devs are really good about listening to our -very- small community. 

I am changing this from a Down Vote to an Up Vote -ONLY- because I believe in this game and our Devs. And if you've been here since the beginning like me, I think you should too. 

I've heard word that the guns are being balanced for release into PVP. I love the Shrike, which we already have. Many are calling for the nerf of the Seraph missile launcher, but I think people just need to learn how to play against it.

The PVE is bland and kind of boring. The Faction goals and world map is a great idea and you can spend your PVP earnings into it which is great. I understand we are trying to attract the PVE/casual crowd, but I don't feel as though that is GoI's audience. We want to shank each other... in air ships.

The new ships, lore, guns, and content in general is awesome! I look forward to more in the future! (Maybe a pirate faction...? :o)


Original Post: Let me start by first saying that I -LOVE- Guns of Icarus. That said, I could not give Alliance an upvote as I play solely for the PVP experience. Alliance is catered to PVE players. You cannot use the Faction Guns or Airships in PVP matches. 

Hindsight is 20/20. If I had been fully aware of this, I would not have bothered with the beta -or- purchasing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991922936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 8189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6100, 'last_played': 1532703818}
review:
Flight of Icarus was about a suicidal airship pilot named Gabriel in a dystopian steampunk world. Which was ravaged by plagues, wars and greed of humanity. Then came the Guns of Icarus Online, which was about airship pilots following the footsteps of the protagonist of first game. It was a PvP game and an interesting comcept in its own right. But wasn't advertised too much and known to a small, loyal player-base only.

Then a wild creative idea appeared: A PvE extension! It was a welcome addition for the existing players and also a valid reason to return for me (I'm not a hardcore PvP player).

GoI Alliance, simply puts you on an airship, gives you a wrench and few other things (varies) and wants you to keep that airship afloat and destroying AI controlled airships at the same time.

One of the four players aboard becomes a pilot, who -apparently- pilots the thing. Rest of the crew picks one of the two roles: gunner or engineer. Gunners operate the guns and destroy other things. Engineers repair & maintain everything and keep the giant scrap of metal afloat for others to continue doing their jobs.

Interesting teamwork game for anyone that likes fast paced action. You should try... yes you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198191158355', 'num_games_owned': 67, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 18265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1506, 'last_played': 1551648732}

author: {'steamid': '76561198200538749', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1412, 'last_played': 1554656575}
review:
This is an insanley well made game. I've only played for 6 hrs (at the time of the review) and I love it to pieces. Everything is flawless. The people in the lobbies are very nice to me, and you never need to worry about to long of wait times, because you can browse any tab in the menu while you wait to join a lobby, or while the lobby waits to start. I was lucky enough to find a dude with hundreds of hours in a co-op game, and he tought me all about the faction system. 

Heres the basics of the faction system, because it is a little wacky tacky, and I don't want it to ruin the gorgeus game for anyone:

There are four factions, they fight to qounqer territories, but not in real battles. You play a game, and the points you win go to whichever war effort you signed up for. If a faction conqers those lands, it gets those resources.

Leveling up for a faction can get you faction specific guns abilities ranks, and at approxamatley level seven, a very powerfull faction ship.



I really hope that helped.



I definitley reccomend this game, and would've payed 40 bucks for it, and had no regrets.



There are some cons though, but they are few:

1. The game runs an excelent frame rate, but for some reason, it just shits chrome out.

2. It is a little complicated with the faction system

THATS ALL THE CONS

I would deffinitley reccomend researching factions before you decide, I mean you can change factions, but it takes away reputation points, which i think you use to level up and get the faction items.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047997653', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 10382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1588, 'last_played': 1526723468}
review:
I played GOIOnline a long time ago and was sold on the idea of adventure mode (Alliance), I enjoyed the core gameplay of GOIO but the pvp got repetitive.  As I've grown older I find my desire to pvp has faded while the strategy elements of Alliance combined with the pve boss battles really fits what I'm looking for atm.

This game has the potential to be very addicting, and what's crazy is they bundle both games into one...it's like basically buying the original game plus a huge DLC in a bundle.  I can only wish there was some way to combine the two games even further by making the pvp affect the pve campaign.

I seen very good things for the future of this game when I first purchased it and I am still satisfied with what it's turned out to be now that it's finally out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077793852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 28740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24819, 'last_played': 1641189538}

author: {'steamid': '76561198077718531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 19725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1483, 'last_played': 1642885532}
review:
what is the game:
          PvE expansion to "guns of icarus online." guns of icarus is an online team based airship combat simulator. you pick from 3 classes pilot, gunner, or engineer. each ship carries 4 crew typically 1 pilot 1 gunner 2 engineers. pilot spends almost all his time flying except on a select few ships where he can sometimes shoot or repair one item. gunner spends most time shooting and fixing the guns he shoots, tho helping engineers repair is not uncommon. engineers spend most of their time running around the ship repairing everything, and depending on the ship shooting as well.
          the "alliance" expansion to "guns of icarus online" creates a less competative varient of guns of icarus that is more noob friendly. at the same time the expansion adds unlockable pve ships and guns (test ships/guns that will eventually be balanced and thrown into pvp). the alliance mode is not just for new players dificullty settings, it allows for older players to have a challenge as well.
          "guns of icarus alliance" also adds a faction war system to the game where multable factions fight for control of a risk style map based off decisions made by players in that faction. currently there are 4 factions eventually there will be more.

Pros:
1. comunity is much more polite in pve (pvp varient some experienced players had zero tolarence for new players)
2. grind factor in this game is so low it almost doesnt exzist (only the pve class specails, guns, and ships are unlockables)
3. game is 100% skill based minimal grind means all players are on equal footing (minus the games learning curve)
4. guns/ weapons are unique to eachother and require various amounts of skill to use (praise hades... best gun IMO)
5. pve engineer equipment makes engineering even without shooting more interactive (ship parcore ftw)
6. each ship is unique and its weapons are fully customizeable (putting the right weapons on a ship is key to winning)
7. team based combat makes game great to play with friends (even noobs are deadly when they are cordinated)

Cons:
1. current lack of map variety (only one map per PvE gamemode as far as i can tell)
2. faction conquest/risk feels vert disconnected from the actual combat in game (just click where you want to help fight)
3. lore is awsome but game doesnt do anything to make you feel like your in the world (mostly because lack of maps)
4. very high learning curve (this could be a pro or a con depending on who you are)
5. occasional toxic people (its a 100% multiplayer game even tho pve is more chill than pvp some people are just toxic)
6. forced to fight on blue team in PvE (I HATE BLUE TEAM)
7. no RED ship ornament (also i can only paint bloon Red not hull)

What i think is missing: (some for current build others i expect would require another expansion)
1. to add to map varity and immersion... make climate / background and some models change texture and color to reflect where you are deployed in world map
2. virtual lobby / overlay lobby with the town you are deploying from (make it a default shape similar to map variation idea so you can see other shipmates / crew
3. ground targets / battles (even in modern warfare people dont just fight in the skies)
4. open world to fly in with merchant/pirate style missions with pve and pvp elements (and towns to visit / walk around)
5. ability to create your own airship (limited enough that said ships will stay roughly balanced)
6. ability to paint ship hull (and Red hull paint)
7. more ship ornament (not just a Red one... but i want a RED one)

author: {'steamid': '76561198018772262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2622, 'last_played': 1693701337}
review:
It's been quite the while for the wait, but so far the DLC has been worth the small price it costs. I am arguably biased in that, I have played the base game for more than 2000 hours, but the new implementations have given motivation and purpose to playing it again. Not only do I love the faction war on the world map, it also gives incentive for people to play and aid their faction in the war efforts.

The new ships are a blast to play and the guns are extremely fun to use and wield. The levels of the guns and ships often feel empowering in PVE. Worth every penny.

The AI director isn't entirely perfect, and sometimes you curse how shitty the ship spawns are, but I've found them survivable with a team that's quick to respond. Note that I've only experienced terribly unfair spawns on higher difficulties, and that may be the reason for them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136192878', 'num_games_owned': 307, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1492136487}
